flashcards.english: Second person future tense - today vs tomorrow/beyond
flashcards.notes: Ûgûkîra (you will wake up today) vs Ûgokîra (you will wake up tomorrow+). Key difference: û-vowel for today, o/e-vowels for future days
examples: Ûgwîthamba na maî mahoro (You will bathe with cold water today)
Ûgethamba na maî mahoro (You will bathe with cold water tomorrow)

flashcards.english: First person future tense - tomorrow and beyond
flashcards.notes: Prefixes for 'I will...' starting tomorrow: Ngo-, Nga-, Nge-. Example: Ngokîra (I will wake up), Ngaruga (I will cook)
examples: Ngethamba na maî mahoro (I will bathe with cold water)
Ngahinga mûrango (I will shut/lock the door)
Rûcîû ngokîra dagîka ikûmi ciathira (Tomorrow I will wake up ten minutes later)

flashcards.english: First person future tense - moments later or anytime today
flashcards.notes: Prefixes for 'I will...' later today: Ngû-, Ngwî-. Example: Ngûkîra (I will wake up), Ngwîthamba (I will bathe). Can start with Ûmûthî (today)
examples: Ngwîhumba nguo naihenya (I will put on clothes quickly)
Ngûrûga ûcûrû wa mûûtû wa mûhîa (I will make sorghum porridge)
Ûmûthî ngûcoka hinge mûrango (Today then I will shut the door)

flashcards.notes: Pronouns optional in Kikuyu as verb indicates person. Ndî na = I have, Wî na = You have, E na = He/she has, Me na = They have, Twî na = We have, Mwî na = You (plural) have
examples: Ndî na karamu (I have a pen)
E na ngîrathi yakwa (He/she has my glass)
Me na ngîrathi ciakwa (They have my glasses)
Twî na mwarimû ûngî (We have another teacher)
Mwî na thîna (You all have problems)
